items.label: rem-note-hypocoercivity-analogy
items.title: Analogy to Classical Hypocoercivity Theory
items.content:
992: :class: tip
993: 
994: This structure is the **discrete stochastic analogue** of the classical hypocoercivity framework for kinetic PDEs (Villani, 2009; Dolbeault-Mouhot-Schmeiser, 2015):
995: 
996: **Classical Hypocoercivity (Kinetic Fokker-Planck)**:
997: - The transport operator $v \cdot \nabla_x$ generates dynamics in $x$ but is neutral on the velocity distribution.
998: - The collision operator $\mathcal{L}_v$ generates dissipation in $v$ but does not directly affect $x$.
999: - Neither operator alone contracts the full kinetic norm $\|f\|^2_{L^2} + \|\nabla_x f\|^2_{L^2}$.
1000: - The augmented norm $\|f\|^2_{L^2} + \varepsilon \|\nabla_x f\|^2_{L^2}$ allows proving exponential decay by balancing the operators' effects.
1001: 
1002: **Our Discrete Stochastic Framework (Fragile Gas)**:
1003: - The cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ contracts $V_{\text{Var}}$ (internal swarm structure) but may expand $W_h^2$ (inter-swarm distance via velocity resets).
1004: - The kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}$ contracts $W_h^2$ (via confining potential) but may expand $V_{\text{Var}}$ (via diffusion noise).
1005: - Neither operator alone contracts the full phase-space error.
1006: - The augmented Lyapunov $V_{\text{total}} = W_h^2 + c_V V_{\text{Var}} + c_B W_b$ allows proving exponential convergence by balancing the operators' synergistic dissipation.

items.label: rem-log-gap-bound-tightness
items.title: On the Tightness of the Bound
items.content:
4193: :class: note
4194: 
4195: The stated bound $\ln(1 + \kappa/V_{\max})$ is slightly conservative compared to the tight bound $\ln(1 + \kappa/(V_{\max} - \kappa))$ derived in Step 4. For most practical applications where $\kappa \ll V_{\max}$, the difference is negligible:
4196: 
4197: $$
4198: \frac{\kappa}{V_{\max} - \kappa} \approx \frac{\kappa}{V_{\max}}\left(1 + \frac{\kappa}{V_{\max}}\right)
4199: $$

items.label: rem-log-gap-bound-tight-at-vmin
items.title: Why the Bound is Tight at $V_{\min}$
items.content:
4313: :class: note
4314: 
4315: The upper bound $\ln(1 + \kappa/V_{\min})$ is achieved in the worst-case scenario where:
4316: 1. The means are separated by the maximum allowed gap $\kappa$
4317: 2. Both distributions are positioned at the bottom of the range near $V_{\min}$, where the logarithm has the steepest slope
4318: 3. One distribution is deterministic (maximizing its expected log) while the other is maximally dispersed (minimizing its expected log)

items.content:
5932: :label: rem-measurement-coupling
5933: 
5934: When analyzing two swarms $(S_1, S_2)$ in the drift analysis (Chapters 10-11), we use **synchronous coupling** of the randomness:
5935: - The same random pairing algorithm is applied to both swarms

5932: :label: rem-measurement-coupling
5933: 
5934: When analyzing two swarms $(S_1, S_2)$ in the drift analysis (Chapters 10-11), we use **synchronous coupling** of the randomness:
5935: - The same random pairing algorithm is applied to both swarms
5936: - The PRNG streams are coupled so that walker $i$ in swarm 1 and walker $i$ in swarm 2 use the same random seed

items.label: rem-position-velocity-update-difference
items.title: Position Jitter vs. Velocity Collision Model
items.content:
6203: :label: rem-position-velocity-update-difference
6204: 
6205: The cloning operator treats positions and velocities asymmetrically:
6206: 
6207: 1. **Position:** Stochastic Gaussian jitter with variance $\sigma_x^2$ breaks spatial correlations between swarms in the drift analysis.
6208: 
6209: 2. **Velocity:** Deterministic inelastic collision model (with random rotation) conserves momentum and provides controlled energy dissipation via $\alpha_{\text{restitution}}$.
6210: 
6211: This design choice has important implications:
6212: 
6213: - **Positional desynchronization** comes from explicit Gaussian noise $\mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_x^2 I_d)$

6214: - **Velocity desynchronization** comes from the random rotations $R_k$ in the collision model, which randomize velocity directions while preserving or reducing magnitudes

items.label: rem-coupling-benefits
items.title: Synchronous Coupling Benefits
items.content:
6392: :label: rem-coupling-benefits
6393: 
6394: The synchronous coupling ensures that:
6395: 
6396: 1. **Common randomness cancels:** When both swarms have walker $i$ in similar states and both make the same cloning decision, much of the random perturbation is shared, reducing divergence.
6397: 
6398: 2. **Worst-case expansion is bounded:** Even when the swarms make different decisions (e.g., walker $i$ clones in swarm 1 but persists in swarm 2), the expansion is controlled by the maximum displacement $D_{\text{valid}}$.

items.label: rem-synergistic-velocity-dissipation
items.title: Synergistic Dissipation Enables Net Contraction
items.content:
6883: :label: rem-synergistic-velocity-dissipation
6884: 
6885: This bounded expansion is the prerequisite for the synergistic dissipation framework. The companion document will prove that the kinetic operator provides velocity contraction:
6886: 
6887: $$
6888: \mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} + C'_v
6889: $$
6890: 
6891: for some $\kappa_v > 0$ proportional to the Langevin friction $\gamma$.
6892: 
6893: When properly balanced:
6894: 
6895: $$
6896: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone} \circ \text{kin}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} + (C_v + C'_v)
6897: $$

items.label: rem-drift-constants-dependencies
items.title: Constants and Parameter Dependencies
items.content:
7028: :label: rem-drift-constants-dependencies
7029: 
7030: The drift constants have the following dependencies:
7031: 
7032: **Contraction rate $\kappa_x$:**
7033: - Increases with measurement quality (larger $\epsilon$ → better diversity detection)
7034: - Increases with cloning responsiveness (larger $p_{\max}$ and smaller $\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}$)
7035: - Independent of $N$ (N-uniformity from Keystone)
7036: 
7037: **Expansion bound $C_v$:**
7038: - Increases with $V_{\max}^2$ (larger velocity domain)
7039: - Increases with $\alpha_{\text{restitution}}$ (more elastic collisions)
7040: - Decreases toward zero as $\alpha_{\text{restitution}} \to 0$ (perfectly inelastic)
7041: - Independent of $N$

items.label: rem-barrier-geometric-penalty
items.title: Barrier Function as Geometric Penalty
items.content:
7119: :label: rem-barrier-geometric-penalty
7120: 
7121: The barrier function creates a "soft wall" around the boundary:
7122: 
7123: - **Far from boundary** ($d(x, \partial \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}) > \delta_{\text{safe}}$): No penalty, $\varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x) = 0$
7124: 
7125: - **Near boundary** ($d(x, \partial \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}) \leq \delta_{\text{safe}}$): Penalty increases, reducing fitness
7126: 
7127: - **At boundary:** Infinite penalty (though walkers at the boundary are dead, so this limit is never realized for alive walkers)

items.label: rem-boundary-mass-relationship
items.title: Relationship to Total Boundary Potential
items.content:
7326: :label: rem-boundary-mass-relationship
7327: 
7328: If all walkers outside the exposed set have $\varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_i) \leq \phi_{\text{thresh}}$, then:
7329: 
7330: $$
7331: W_b(S_k) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}(S_k)} \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_i) \leq M_{\text{boundary}}(S_k) + \frac{k_{\text{alive}}}{N} \phi_{\text{thresh}}
7332: $$

items.label: rem-progressive-safety
items.title: Interpretation: Progressive Safety Enhancement
items.content:
7358: :label: rem-progressive-safety
7359: 
7360: This theorem formalizes the Safe Harbor mechanism:
7361: 
7362: - **When many walkers are near the boundary** ($W_b$ large), these walkers have low fitness and high cloning probability
7363: - **They are replaced by clones of interior walkers**, pulling the boundary potential down
7364: - **The contraction rate $\kappa_b$ is state-independent**, ensuring consistent safety correction regardless of swarm configuration
7365: - **The bounded offset $C_b$** accounts for walkers entering the boundary region through position jitter, but this is dominated by contraction when $W_b$ is large
7366: 
7367: **Important Consequences:**

items.label: rem-safety-margin-tuning
items.title: Safety Margin and Parameter Tuning
items.content:
7765: :label: rem-safety-margin-tuning
7766: 
7767: The equilibrium bound $C_b/\kappa_b$ can be made arbitrarily small by:
7768: 
7769: 1. **Increasing $\kappa_b$:** Use larger weight $\beta$ on the reward component in fitness, making boundary penalties more salient
7770: 
7771: 2. **Decreasing $C_b$:** Use smaller position jitter variance $\sigma_x^2$ to reduce re-entry into boundary regions after cloning
7772: 
7773: 3. **Widening safe interior:** Choose barrier function parameters to increase $\delta_{\text{safe}}$, providing more buffer before penalties activate

items.label: rem-why-vw-expands
items.title: Why Inter-Swarm Error Doesn't Contract Under Cloning
items.content:
8018: :label: rem-why-vw-expands
8019: 
8020: The cloning operator **cannot contract** $V_W$ because:
8021: 
8022: 1. **Intra-swarm mechanism:** Cloning acts **within** each swarm independently. It compares walker $i$ to its companion in the **same swarm**, not to the corresponding walker in the other swarm.
8023: 
8024: 2. **No inter-swarm communication:** The fitness evaluation and companion selection have no information about the other swarm in the coupled analysis. They cannot "know" which direction reduces $V_W$.
8025: 
8026: 3. **Stochastic desynchronization:** Even with synchronous coupling, different swarm configurations lead to different fitness landscapes, causing different cloning decisions that increase divergence.

items.label: rem-perfect-complementarity
items.title: Perfect Complementarity
items.content:
8281: :label: rem-perfect-complementarity
8282: 
8283: Notice the **exact complementarity**:
8284: - What cloning **contracts** (position, boundary), kinetic **expands** (diffusion, potential climb)
8285: - What cloning **expands** (velocity, inter-swarm), kinetic **contracts** (friction, hypocoercivity)
8286: - Both **contract** the boundary potential (layered safety)

items.label: rem-tuning-guidance
items.title: Tuning Guidance
items.content:
8437: :label: rem-tuning-guidance
8438: 
8439: In practice, the coupling constants are chosen as:
8440: 
8441: $$
8442: c_V \approx \frac{\kappa_W}{2\kappa_x}, \quad c_B \approx \frac{\kappa_W}{2\kappa_b}
8443: $$
8444: 
8445: This balances the contraction rates across components, ensuring no single component dominates the drift inequality. The factor of 2 provides safety margin.
8446: 
8447: If the system is experiencing:
8448: - **High boundary exposure:** Increase $c_B$ to weight safety more heavily
